error.signature: ReferenceError: require is not defined in ES module scope, you can use import instead
error.regex: require is not defined in ES module scope

verdict.summary: Code uses require() inside an ES module. When package.json has "type": "module" or the file has .mjs extension, require() is not available.

dead_ends.action: Adding a polyfill for require in ESM context
dead_ends.why_fails: Fragile workaround that breaks module resolution semantics and can cause subtle bugs with __dirname and __filename

dead_ends.action: Renaming files from .mjs to .js without changing package.json type field
dead_ends.why_fails: If package.json has "type": "module", all .js files are still treated as ESM

workarounds.action: Replace require() calls with import statements or dynamic import()
workarounds.how: Change const x = require('x') to import x from 'x' (static) or const x = await import('x') (dynamic)

workarounds.action: Use createRequire to get a require function in ESM
workarounds.how: import { createRequire } from 'module'; const require = createRequire(import.meta.url); const pkg = require('./package.json');
workarounds.condition: when you need to require JSON files or CJS-only packages

leads_to.condition: when switching module systems causes the inverse error

preceded_by.condition: when developers switch to ESM after encountering import errors in CJS

frequently_confused_with.distinction: This error means require() was used inside an ESM file, while ERR_REQUIRE_ESM means a CJS file tried to require() an ESM-only package
